items.title: Ada Louise Huxtable, Champion of Livable Architecture, Dies at 91
items.abstract: Ms. Huxtable pioneered modern architectural criticism in The New York Times, celebrating buildings that respected human dignity and civic history.

items.title: Nashville’s Latest Big Hit Could Be the City Itself
items.abstract: The city, which sat on the sidelines while its Southern sisters boomed, has found itself in the national spotlight, with economic gains and a newly found popularity.

items.title: An Urban Standard, Coolly Reimagined
items.abstract: William Lescaze’s 1935 Kramer house, like many Modernist houses, is not weathering well.

items.title: New York City Ties Doctors’ Income to Quality of Care
items.abstract: A proposal affecting physicians in public hospitals represents a push away from the traditional model of rewarding doctors for the volume of the services they order.
keywords: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

items.title: Museum of Arts and Design Director Announces Departure
items.abstract: Holly Hotchner announced she will step down in April, after 16 years in charge.

items.title: California Beach City Enlists Private Partner to Rejuvenate Pier
items.abstract: Redondo Beach, once a major tourist destination, no longer attracts crowds of visitors. A $250 million public-private project to redevelop its faded waterfront aims to change that.

items.title: New York Council May Vote on Raise and Horse-Carriage Bill on Same Day
items.abstract: As the Council completed a package of bills on lawmakers’ raises, questions surfaced about possible links to a bill shrinking the horse-cab industry.

items.title: Maastricht Art Fair Widens Its Reach, to New York
items.abstract: Tefaf’s New York venture — essentially two new boutique shows — is an audacious move at a time when New York’s calendar has never been more crowded with high-end fairs.

items.title: Mayor de Blasio Lays Out Vision for New York in State of the City Address
items.abstract: The mayor adapted his liberal ambitions to a broad range of projects aimed at the everyday dangers and inconveniences of New York City life.

items.title: 5 Notable Quotes From Mayor Bill de Blasio’s State of the City Speech
items.abstract: The mayor’s speech did not convey an overarching theme in service of a single policy initiative as much as it offered proposals that the city could do largely on its own.

items.title: The Army, in Need of Recruits, Turns Focus to Liberal-Leaning Cities
items.abstract: Too few recruits are signing up from cities like Chicago and Seattle, so the Army is trying to frame enlistment as a patriotic detour.
keywords: United States Defense and Military Forces

items.title: What’s Coming in New York Real Estate in 2019
items.abstract: An already soft market will get another 20,000 new apartments, making it an even stronger buyer’s and renter’s market.

items.title: Students in Rural America Ask, ‘What Is a University Without a History Major?’
items.abstract: Financial and enrollment woes at schools like the University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point have led to a scramble for fixes, such as dropping longstanding liberal arts degrees.

items.title: N.Y. Draws a Record 65 Million Tourists (in Spite of Trump’s Trade War, Many Were Chinese)
items.abstract: The number of visitors to New York City climbed for the ninth year, led by tourists from the United States, the United Kingdom, China and Canada.

items.title: To Save East River Park, the City Intends to Bury It
items.abstract: A plan to protect the Lower East Side from flooding was just rejected by the city, replaced with a drastic revision that costs twice as much but does not disrupt traffic.

items.title: Manchester City, Chelsea and Competing With Perfection
items.abstract: Pep Guardiola’s ideas and his teams have changed the way England views the game. The danger is that those changes affect perceptions of what qualifies as success.

items.title: After Urban Flight, Corporate Campuses Add a Taste of the City
items.abstract: Suburban headquarters are being redesigned to add more amenities that will integrate better with their communities and attract the skilled workers.

items.title: Boerum Hill, Brooklyn: A ‘Village in the City’
items.abstract: With its desirable 19th-century rowhouses and convenient subway access, the neighborhood is both homey and worldly.

items.title: House Hunting in Mexico City: Wood and Marble Mingle in a Stylish Triplex
items.abstract: Investors ‘are selling properties in Mexico City to reinvest in other countries,’ local agents say, boosting inventory and tamping down prices.

items.title: The N.F.L. Wants to Be a Player in a City of Players
items.abstract: The league’s new West Coast headquarters, in the shadow of SoFi Stadium, gives it a large footprint in the land of big media deals.
